post_text:
School's Pillar of the Year

The concept of a pillar is that it works in tandem with others to offer strength and support to a structure. Architecturally, it is meant to stand out and to represent the best aspects of the structure. Without the pillar, the structure would lose its strength and some of its beauty. So too with the Pillar of Bethel. This award honors a non-certified staff members, parent, or community member who:

Has made exemplary efforts, either individually or as a part of a team or group, to go above and beyond expectations to improve the school;

Has created extraordinary opportunities for children and stimulates or allows others to be their best.

Is recognized as a role model for others.

Community Update from the Department of Public Health (we could not agree more):

The Compassion of Staying Home to Save Others

A lot of thanks and appreciation has been rightly expressed to essential workers who have continued to work through the pandemic. These individuals are heroes and deserve our gratitude. There is another group of people that also deserve some appreciation. Those residents who have tested positive with no or few symptoms or been in contact with someone who has tested positive and willingly stayed home in isolation and/or quarantine. By doing this they probably kept 2-3 other people from getting infected. Since we do not know yet who will get severe illness or may even die, it is important to recognized this act of compassion. Those who stayed home and followed the isolation/quarantine rules, saved lives. Thank you to all who have shown this act of compassion and to all that will be asked to do so in the future. May your illness be mild and your closets be neat and clean. Thank you! You are Isolation & Quarantine Heroes!

Mr. Troetti wrote this email to his students today. At BPS, we all share in his sentiments. Please reach out if we can support you or your family in any way.

Dear Students,

First, I hope this email finds you healthy and safe.

As we have seen troubling events unfold over the past week, I have been searching for the words to address all of you in a way that is meaningful and supportive, despite not being together at Bethel High School. The disturbing circumstances around George Floyd's death have likely stirred many negative feelings, including but not limited to anger, anxiety, despair, and horror. How this injustice could happen is a question that we are forced to ponder far too often; I wish I had answers that would lead to immediate solutions. What I do know is that our strength lies in our ability to support each other. With that in mind, if any of you would like to speak with me or another staff member, please don't hesitate to reach out.

Sincerely,

Mr. Troetti

A question I have received about the school calendar: ‚ÄúThe Governor said we do not have to do the 180 days because of COVID - How did we come up with the revised school calendar?‚Äù

A: We got further guidance/clarification on a conference call with the Commissioner of Education. He clarified that it is still the district's responsibility to try and get to 180. The Governor was more broadly speaking about districts that could not get in all of the time before June 30th. Here is how we came to June 16th. We had two snow days in November/December. That brought the original calendar to June 15th, which included 181 days (original school calendar). We changed the total number of student days to 180. We had 6 missed days for COVID. We are making up 4 days in April Break. That brings us to June 16th! Hope that helps to clarify.
